citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
A dog was identified at the facility needing veterinary care. The facility did not identify the issue prior to the inspection. An
adult female Boston Terrier (#8171) was found to have areas of redness and hair loss on the front paws. On both front
paws, there is an area on the outermost digit measuring approximately ½ inch that is moderately reddened with hair loss.
The adjacent areas near this site are also mildly reddened. On both front legs there are additional smaller areas of hair
loss and redness located above the paws. The facility states the animal has not been seen scratching or irritating the site
and during the inspection the animal did not appear irritated when the site was manipulated.
Failure to conduct adequate daily observations to assess the health and well-being of the animals with direct and frequent
communication to the attending veterinarian can delay treatment leading to the condition getting worse and delays in
healing. Each dealer shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include daily observation of
all animals to assess their health and well-being and that a mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required
so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the
attending veterinarian. Correct by ensuring that the animal is examined and treated by a licensed veterinarian.

The facility is not following the written Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) regarding an adult female Boston Terrier
(#9830). The facility observed that the animal was scratching their ears and had been treating the animal with an ear
cleaner. The PVC states to clean the ears twice daily but the facility had been cleaning the ears only once daily. Failure to
follow the preventative care and treatment plan in the PVC can cause pain and distress to the regulated animal. Correct
by ensuring that the preventative care and treatment plan in the PVC is followed.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by March 9, 2026 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
A dog was identified at the facility needing veterinary care. The facility did not identify the issue prior to the inspection. An 
adult female Boston Terrier (#8171) was found to have areas of redness and hair loss on the front paws. On both front 
paws, there is an area on the outermost digit measuring approximately ½ inch that is moderately reddened with hair loss. 
The adjacent areas near this site are also mildly reddened. On both front legs there are additional smaller areas of hair 
loss and redness located above the paws. The facility states the animal has not been seen scratching or irritating the site 
and during the inspection the animal did not appear irritated when the site was manipulated. 
 
Failure to conduct adequate daily observations to assess the health and well-being of the animals with direct and frequent 
communication to the attending veterinarian can delay treatment leading to the condition getting worse and delays in 
healing. Each dealer shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include daily observation of 
all animals to assess their health and well-being and that a mechanism of direct and frequent communication is required 
so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the 
attending veterinarian. Correct by ensuring that the animal is examined and treated by a licensed veterinarian. 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility is not following the written Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) regarding an adult female Boston Terrier 
(#9830). The facility observed that the animal was scratching their ears and had been treating the animal with an ear 
cleaner. The PVC states to clean the ears twice daily but the facility had been cleaning the ears only once daily. Failure to 
follow the preventative care and treatment plan in the PVC can cause pain and distress to the regulated animal. Correct 
by ensuring that the preventative care and treatment plan in the PVC is followed. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by March 9, 2026 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.

Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
